title: 110_hr638
content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms related to high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including the roles of Governors and the criteria for designation. The Attorney General can designate specified areas within states based on certain criteria to receive federal assistance. The Attorney General can provide Federal assistance to high-intensity interstate gang activity areas by establishing criminal street gang enforcement teams consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities for coordinated investigation, disruption, apprehension, and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders in those areas. Personnel can be reassigned or detailed from any Federal department or agency, with necessary funding provided for the operation of these enforcement teams. The Attorney General can establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, consisting of agents and officers from various federal agencies. Funding is provided for the operation and coordination of these teams, including national and regional meetings for sharing intelligence and best practices. The Attorney General can designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas and consider criteria such as gang crime levels, violent crime related to gangs, and resources committed by law enforcement agencies. The Attorney General is authorized to hire additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities in designated high-intensity interstate areas. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims of crimes. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to allow hiring additional prosecutors, funding technology and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders, and prosecuting young violent offenders. Authorization of appropriations is also amended. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to authorize appropriations of $20,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. Additionally, grants are provided to State and local law enforcement for establishing State-wide crime prevention databases to track criminals, arrests, prosecutions, and convictions.
